title: Friday, 27th November, 2015
bodyHTML:

11:14 am
BE

Sheesh

BE

Was trying to do the maths on Anglo's stake in South African Breweries, which it sold in 1999.

11:15 am
BE

Well, the parent of South African Breweries, which was the parent of SABMiller .....

BE

Can't pin down exact figures, because 1999 is before recorded history for most financial news providers. But it seems Anglo had about an economic interest of about 15% in SAB.

BE

That'd be £10bn or thereabouts today.

11:17 am
BE

Against Anglo's current market cap of £5bn or thereabouts.

PM

Amazing value destruction

BE

I see the "De Beers IPO" idea's back on the right.

11:18 am
BE

To answer: no.

BE

Anglo has no immediate problems with debt. It doesn't need to raise money.

BE

And selling a stake in its biggest business in a cyclical depression for the diamond market would be seen as a firesale.

11:19 am
BE

.... A fire sale by a CEO who hasn't even seen a reason to cut the divi yet.

BE

Let me cut back to that HSBC note from earlier in the week.

BE

De Beers IPO: price discovery could unlock value, timing is key

Anglo’s diamond portfolio offers unique diversification amongst the majors, and has a potentially compelling long-term story. We think De Beers would likely attract a premium valuation (vs traditional miners) as a standalone, and believe a partial sale through IPO could be, under the right market conditions, a powerful price discovery mechanism in addition to being significant cash boost. We think Anglo might look to retain a stake in an IPO, for diversification.

Valuation: In 2011 Anglo announced a USD5.1bn acquisition of the Oppenheimer family’s 40% stake, implying USD10.8bn for Anglo’s current 85% ownership (or USD12.75bn 100% basis). De Beers achieved USD1.7bn EBITDA in 2011 (100%), pointing to an acquisition price of 7.5x EBITDA. In 2013 Swatch acquired Harry Winston for an implied c.13.5x EBITDA. On today’s “trough” earnings of c.USD1.0-1.5bn EBITDA, we think Anglo’s full De Beers stake could potentially fetch upwards of USD10bn in an IPO, although a partial sale through IPO would retain diamonds earnings exposure and maintain diversification.

Sale impact and timing: Assuming a 60% ownership stake sale on an illustrative USD10bn valuation (100% basis) points to USD6bn proceeds and Anglo retaining 25%. That said, today’s market appetite is low, and we think Anglo is likely to wait for a cyclical recovery before realistically considering a separation. Exceeding the implied Oppenheimer stake purchase price would likely be the minimum company expectation, in our view. Near term, we are entering the seasonal strong demand period, which will help define diamond profitability prospects over the coming year.

11:21 am
BE

The upshot here is that Anglo would be selling its best business to fund Kumba, its worst business.

PM

ha

BE

(Though the title of "worst" is a crowded field.)

11:22 am
undefined

11:22 am
PM

From James Edwardes Jones, at RBC

PM

Since 16th September, when ABI’s pursuit of SABMiller became public, the combined market capitalisation of ABI and SABMiller has increased by €75bn, or 25%. Relative to a buoyant sector, it has put on the equivalent of the market cap of Danone.

PM

That's crazy, no?

11:23 am
PM

Mr Edwardes Jones seems to think so

PM

It’s no surprise that SABMiller has outperformed the consumer staples sector. Less predictable, at least by us, is the extent to which ABI has also outperformed. It has risen 13% relative to the sector over the last month. That is similar to the 15% EPS accretion we foresee from the acquisition (see our report ‘Touch too much’, 14 October 2015). We're in a quandary.

PM

Management’s track record in M&A is exceptional. If anyone can create the value the share price is implying, we back the ABI team. But at the very least, we wonder if the share price reaction isn’t premature. Value accretion is not the same as EPS accretion, yet the latter is what ABI share price seems to be reflecting. ABI intends to acquire an already efficient business with substantial emerging market exposure (good long term growth prospects but relatively high risk) that it’s financing in large part with US$ borrowings. There are elements of a carry trade here in our view. We believe the risks are weighted to the downside. We retain our Sector Perform recommendation and €100 price target.

11:23 am
PM

A bit crazy

PM

market ahead of itself on ABI

SABMiller PLC (SAB:LSE): Last: 4,031, up 6 (+0.15%), High: 4,031, Low: 4,011, Volume: 291.41k

11:27 am
BE

In terms of the sellside, Caz downgrade of Imagination Technologies has caused most interest.

BE

We foresee a growth issue in 2HFY16 that will impact performance of the
stock due to timing of new wins, the difficult comps at key customer Apple,
ongoing semi inventory correction, which will cause decline at a number of
Chinese customers, and product decline at a major customer before new
product ramps up. We downgrade the stock to Neutral till risk passes and
reduce our Dec-16 PT to 230p (275p, Apr-16).

BE

Fiscal 2HFY16 growth challenging. Despite the loss of Mediatek's phone
platforms in FY14 and 15, which may have resulted in the loss of 300m or
more units, Imagination saw essentially flat royalty units in both years due
to very strong growth at Apple, which uses its graphics & video IPR in the
iPhone & iPad. In 2HFY16 however, IMG faces multiple issues, including:
i. Apple comps in calendar 4Q15 and 1Q16 are difficult, meaning even if
Apple is flat year on year in those quarters, the market will see that as
positive (JPM estimate of iPhone and iPad volume in this period is for a
1.5% decline year on year), however, a flat environment would be negative
for Imagination; ii. Semiconductor inventory correction is ongoing, with
particular impact in China & emerging markets. Imagination has exposure
to a number of companies shipping into these markets, causing risk to
estimates; iii. An unnamed large customer stopped shipping an old chip
containing Imagination IP, with no outlook when the next generation chip
will begin shipping; this issue could have continuing impact in 2HFY16.

11:28 am
BE

New wins only likely to begin shipping in end calendar '16/early '17,
causing 2HFY16 pause: Imagination has won key new wins in graphics for
application processors & has also won some key wins for MIPS technology
in mobile market but also improved MIPS position in old and new markets.
These new wins are likely to start ramping from end calendar ’16 at the
earliest but given typical tech delays this could even be early '17 in our view.

BE

Cutting FY16 and FY17 estimates: It is very likely this lack of growth is
centered on 2HFY16 only & IMG royalties return to growth in 1HFY17.
However, with the above listed headwinds to estimates, we believe stock
performance in calendar 1H16 will be difficult. Due to lower royalty
revenue estimates, our 1H, FY16 and FY17 group revenue estimates are
0.8%, 3.7% and 5.9% lower, with EBIT cut by ~33% and 40% in FY16E
and FY17E. Due to these cuts, we downgrade to Neutral, waiting for the risk
to pass before getting more constructive on FY17 growth potential.

BE

Imagination has interims due December 15, around which the risks are obvious.

11:29 am
BE

BE

11:36 am
BE

Here's RBC again, from last week.

BE

Balance sheet focus pertinent: Earlier this year Petra raised US$300m in
high-yield bonds to fund the new plant (~US$145m) and to restructure
debt. Other than for the new plant, new debt capacity appeared only
slightly necessary. Given what has happened to rough prices (down ~20%
in the past 18 months), the additional liquidity and debt headroom is
welcome. Unlike some of its peers, which do not have the same growth
profiles, Petra's balance sheet health will probably be the most closely
watched investment metric over the next year as capex peaks during a
time of soft diamond prices, even though a weak ZAR is a major benefit.

BE

Stressing the finances: We have built various scenarios to stress-test
Petra's balance sheet, examining cash flow and absolute debt levels, as
well as adherence to covenants. Our conclusion is that under all scenarios,
the capex programme can be funded with existing debt facilities. However,
this will likely result in a debt covenant breach at some point. We believe
that should it need, Petra has some flexibility including deferring some
capex and looking to banks for additional capacity, as well as relaxation
of covenants. On our base case, new equity is not needed. Provided
rough prices start picking up in 2017, we believe the company remains
able to continue to develop the production growth which underlies the
investment thesis. But being financially leveraged and with still significant
capex, the stock will likely remain vulnerable to bad news in the diamond
market.

Crafted from Norwegian blue spruce by our skilled florists, this design features clusters of dried clemantines, sliced oranges, pine cones and bundles of cinnamon. Each luxury Christmas wreath is finished with a chic ribbon to secure.

Image shows our Deluxe (26 inch diameter) Christmas wreath design. Smaller sizes are as follows: Large (22 inch diameter) & Medium (18 inch diameter).

Thoughtfully designed and beautifully created, each of our luxury wreaths are freshly made to order by our team of skilled florists and presented in our elegant white signature box along with handfuls of tissue paper and secured with our chic, branded ribbon. A handwritten card is included with every online order and a personalised message can be added during the checkout process.

We are upgrading our recommendation to BUY as we think (i) Betfair can grow
revenues/profits materially above the market growth rate following the
relentless focus on product innovation coupled with brand investment over the
past 24 months, (ii) we see upside risks to forecasts and (ii) the upcoming
merger with Paddy Power offers the ability to leverage higher returns on
incremental investment given the material increase in scale.

Betfair Group PLC (BET:LSE): Last: 3,662, up 60 (+1.67%), High: 3,663, Low: 3,628, Volume: 122.26k
11:44 am
BE

H1/16E revenue increased +15% to £274m and sustainable revenue +24%.
EBITDA increased 9% to £80m or +45% pre adsorbing the £27m of POC tax.
Earnings increased 23% as DA was held steady and DPS increased +67% to
15p.

BE

Given the group sustainable market growth of plus 20% over the past 7
quarters, we are lifting our medium-term sustainable revenue growth
assumptions for the group’s core Sports and Gaming segments to 15% in
FY16E and FY17E from 10%. However, given the group’s market leading
products, rising marketing budget of c.£120m, and UK market share of only
c12%, we think our 15% growth assumption could prove conservative.

BE

We have increased FY16E EBITDA by 19% to £136m and EPS by 23% to 96p
based on strong core Betfair revenue growth. For FY17E, we have increased
EPS by 22% to 116p and assume EBITDA grows of 18% to £161m.

11:44 am
BE

Our FY16E EPS of 96p now stands 14% ahead of Bloomberg consensus and in
FY17E 17% ahead.

BE

We continue to value Betfair using a SOTP analysis. Our methodology delivers
an updated TP of £42.00 & values the core business on 20x EBITDA and US on
15x EBITDA. We have also included £35m of cost synergies, but not revenue
synergies which we think could be substantial. Downside risks: negative
regulatory developments, rising player acquisition costs & rising competition.

BE

Good business heading into a risky time ahead with a difficult valuation. I'd be a bit more cautious, personally.

BE

We are removing the 5% risk discount that we have imposed on BAE Systems as we
now believe that the risks to defence budgets have been reduced following the UK
SDSR, CSR and the expected 2 year US budget deal by mid-December. This would increase our valuation to 536p. We have also included the estimated 40-50p value per share coming from Saudi batch 2 Eurofighter Typhoon, which we do expect to come at
some time, possibly in H1 2016, taking our price target to 580p

BE

Following the SDSR and yesterday's CSR, we believe that the outlook for UK defence
(25% of sales) is clearer now than any time since the financial crisis. As well, France
potentially breaching the EU stability pact due to higher defence spending indicates a
general willingness to allow for budget flexibility given heightened security concerns.
Meanwhile, we expect the US (35-40% of sales) to sign the appropriations bill for two
years of defence spending to be signed by 11 th December (when the current
Continuing Resolution runs out), again increasing the visibility for BAE Systems.

11:53 am
BE

We previously derisked our forecasts, excluding any new Typhoon sales as we believed
that the market was concerned about near term risks at BAE Systems. We believe that
Saudi will order a second batch of Eurofighter aircraft as (1) the requirement for 5
squadrons (an additional 48 aircraft) was established 10-15 years ago, when the oil
price was well below current levels; (2) the threat level in the Middle East is increasing.
We are therefore including the associated 40-50p NPV in our valuation.

BE

Our PT of 580p is based on a fundamental valuation of 540p using cash conversion of
88%, 5 year profit growth of 2% and a WACC of 9%, implying a fair value multiple of
11.7x EV/EBITA. We have also included Saudi batch 2 (not in our financial forecasts)
adding a further 40-50p.

BE

That's from yesterday, clearly.

Bullet points are ............

BE

- Acceleration of planned F-35 deliveries, so that there will be 24 available for the two new aircraft carriers by 2023, versus the prior target of 8
- Plans to acquire 9 Boeing P-8 maritime patrol aircraft
- 10 year life extension of the RAF's Eurofighter fleet, with upgrades to give them land attack capability
- Revised cost estimate for the next generation of 4 SSBNs, now expected to cost £31bn (+£6bn versus prior estimate). Given the complexity, another £10bn
contingency has also been included.
- Only planning to buy 8 Type 26 frigates, versus prior plans to buy 13
- Additional investment in special forces, UAVs, cyber security and intelligence
- Reiteration of the target to spend at least 2% of GDP on defense, in line with the NATO target

11:55 am

BE

As this an overarching strategic document with a long term perspective, we think that it has more bearing on overall defense sentiment rather than
company specifics. Overall, we would say that if the SDSR is implemented as planned, then it is generally positive. The UK is set to spend more in high priority
areas, whilst also committing itself to expensive strategic purchases like the F-35 and SSBN. Contrary to recent press reports, the P-8 is now back in the plan.
As the UK domestic champion, we would say that the SDSR is good for BAE Systems, and probably other suppliers and US defense primes.

Let me share for non-premium subscribers

PM

Slater & Gordon: Objection!

“Your honour, a publicly traded law firm is a vile innovation that threatens the very foundations of The Law. The conflicts of interest are odious. An example must be made of Slater & Gordon. My client deserves full compensation for her pain!”

The man in the shiny suit gestures dramatically towards the plaintiff, a little old lady from Adelaide who lost A$29.52 punting on Slater’s shares. She is suing for $12m. The evidence: a 54 per cent drop in Sydney-listed Slater’s shares on Thursday. That followed a signal from UK lawmakers that they might restrict personal injury claims. More than half the firm’s business is in the UK.

Counsel is just getting going; 15 per cent of Slater’s shares were sold short before the news. The company’s accounting is the subject of an investigation by Australia’s Securities and Investment Commission. It has revised its accounting practices, coining a metric — “ebitdaw”, or earnings before interest, taxation, depreciation, amortisation and movements in work in progress.

Objection, your honour! Cash flow, not profits, is the issue. Exhibit A: the company’s own guidance, stating that $30-40m is set to flow out of its coffers in the first half. Expert witnesses at CLSA say it will need to generate six years of gross cash flow in the second half to meet its “ebitdaw” target. This matters, because Slater is heavily leveraged. Net debt was $625m at end-June, almost equal to its market value. The debt was amassed by paying cash for legal practices and a division of Quindell, the scandal-hit UK services group. This is odd; a key reason for a roll-up company to have a listing is to obtain a non-cash “acquisition currency”.

BE

(You're all premium to us, ROTR.)

11:57 am
PM

(Bless)

PM

BE

We reduce our rating from Buy to Hold based on the increased earnings and
balance sheet risk profile. This follows the soft 1H update provided at last
week’s AGM and the UK Government overnight proposing changes which, if
implemented, may materially adversely impact the SGS Fast Track RTA
operations. Although SGH reaffirmed FY16 cash earnings guidance, regulatory
change presents significant risk and uncertainty to FY17 and beyond. Our Bear
Case scenario sees FY17 EBITDAW fall 21% yoy (27% downgrade) and
ND/EBITDAW increase to 3.4x (suggesting an equity injection). Balancing this,
the share price has fallen significantly and regulation may not change.
Proposed UK regulatory changes negative for Fast Track RTA volumes
Coming as a surprise to SGH (and the market), the UK Government overnight
announced proposals which, if implemented, will potentially adversely impact
SGH’s Fast Track road traffic accidents (RTA) volumes and earnings from
FY17. The UK Government proposes restricting RTA compensation rights for
pain and suffering in minor soft tissue injury claims, as well as increasing the
limit of the Small Claims Court from £1,000 to £5,000. A consultation process
is scheduled to begin in the new year. RTA cases make up c.95% of core legal
cases (excl. NIHL) in SGS Legal Services while industry estimates that c.70% of
RTA case volumes relate to claims with a value of less than £5,000.
Bear Case scenario derives 16.4c FY17 cash EPS ($137m equity raise @ $0.75)
Running a Bear Case scenario to assess the potential downside from the
proposed UK regulatory changes results in a 27% downgrade to our FY17
EBITDAW forecast with ND/EBITDAW increasing to 3.4x (assuming FY16
earnings guidance is met and scrapping the FY17 dividend). Targeting 2.5x
ND/EBITDAW requires a c.$137m equity raise (20% disc. implies $0.75ps,
increasing the share base by 52% and implying 4.6x FY17f cash EPS of 16.4c).
Valuation and risks
$1.65PT (prev. $3.35), reflecting our lower capitalization multiple. We now
capitalize our $0.33 yr-fwd cash EPS estimate (unchanged) at 5x (prev. 10x) to
reflect regulatory risks, risks to FY16 guidance, balance sheet risks and
prevailing negative investor sentiment which will likely take time to restore.
Key upside/downside risks: regulation; competition; M&A; cash flow.

BE

Investment view: Downgrade to HOLD with revised DCF valuation of A$2.31
(prev. A$5.43) and price target of A$1.20 (prev. A$5.45) with High risk rating
retained. We have discounted our price target relative to our valuation based
on the potential for remedial action that may need to occur in respect of the
balance sheet. We recently upgraded to BUY at A$3.12 with the view that the
share price at that time did not reflect the risk return equation in our view; the
proposed UK legislative changes dramatically changes any assessment of the
risk/return equation. We prefer Shine Corporate (SHJ) where we have a BUY
and A$3.50 price target in this space. SHJ’s market rating has been negatively
impacted by SGH despite no presence in the UK.

BE

Impact on SGH: We summarise the impacts on SGH if the legislative
changes proceed as: 1) Australia: no impact; 2) SGH UK: modest negative
impact; and 3) Slater Gordon Solutions (SGS): material negative impact
potentially impacting around 70% of revenue. Whilst re-modelling SGH’s
earnings is relatively simple at this stage (although still more of a guesstimate
at this stage) the focus at some stage will need to turn to the balance sheet.
SGH took on A$1bn of goodwill in acquiring SGS and at FY15 the group
balance sheet had A$1.4bn in net equity and A$624m in net debt. The
question now is that if the legislative changes proceed, what will SGS need to
be written down by and what implications will that has for bank covenants,
potential capital raisings and possible divestments. We note that SGH’s UK
competitor, Irwin Mitchell undertook a major merger overnight.

Petra has recovered a 23ct pink diamond at the Williamson mine; the mine is known for its pinks. While we caution against attributing value to fancy colours,
we would estimate a price of +$100,000/ct based on the sale in Q3 calendar 2014 of a 16.4ct stone for $2.2m ($134,000/ct). That suggests Petra could realise
$2.3m-$3m. Given soft diamond prices and a still significant capex programme, the additional cash is likely to spur the equity.
